4I_AlFzc9sgNf_Pnhf76Ow.text: Great Italian restaurant. I love the classy atmosphere  I feel welcomed and comfortable there. The service is on a top level and the food is amazing  what more can you need for a nice time out. Recommended.

Ki6cdr3GfDEJRkzkUJxEMw.text: Serves great food but a bit pricy. Staff were also very friendly. Must try this place.

70v1DmK5pPH7JsppBpmxfA.text: Popped in here for lunch today and was so pleasantly surprised - yes, it's not exactly salubrious (though it's fun to sit by the window and watch the Mad Men types going into the agency next door) outside but the food is simply amazing. A fresh, frequently replenished salad bar and a wide choice of hot food. The 'Larder Pie' was gloriously mushroomy and laced with a superb red wine gravy. The absolute hit is the sweet stuff - the peppermint cupcake, laced with mint, was more like a tiny mudcake smothered in pastel frosting. Sublime. Probably the best cupcake I've found in London. After the extensive research we've done, that's really saying something.

1vv5wqnl-1ENO5aEnJHLdg.text: The Table Cafe is a lovely place, very casual with wooden benches and tables. Our NZ server Fohterry was super sweet and comped us an extra dessert of ice cream; sadly the salted caramel was a bit too salty for me. But on the whole the food is great, with unusual ingrediants like black potatoes. The onglet steak was delicious and not at all chewy, as this cut can sometimes be, testimony to good cooking. Also, the wood pidgeon and wild rabbit were perfectly cooked  though they had undersold the wild rabbit on the menu, as it came with beautiful roasted root vegetables. Yummy, sticky toffee puddings. Their head chef is leaving, hope this place stays just as good! Live jazz too sat/fri nights.

vvYJ_gx_u91mcBY6WkwFoQ.text: This is, hands down, the best breakfast in London. The finest ingredients, excellent service, papers at the ready, super strong coffee and The Table Stack. What's The Table Stack, you ask? It's goodness. Goodness piled high, combining all the major necessary food groups needed for a hangover (protein and carbs). If that doesn't float your boat, try the scrambled eggs - they are dreamyness, and for heavenlyness, try the full  English. If I could only eat breakfast for the rest of my (one can dream), I'd do it here. The perfect spot to while away a soggy Sunday. Lush.

uPFvxcME3o5YGUJ-mfzdCA.text: Is it just me or is the name and the map for this place wrong? It's on Southwark St, nowhere near Mayfair... Anyway, I had a really good brunch at The Table on bank holiday Monday - my pancakes with bacon were excellent, and my brunch partner's scrambled eggs were great as well apparently. Accompanied by good coffee, excellent smoothies, a relaxed atmosphere and selection of papers, it's a lovely place to start a lazy day and a good eating option near Tate Modern or London Bridge.

FP6Qk4wWMiQug2Au46FTQg.text: Menu changes fairly often. Not many tables so sometimes bit of a wait to sit down. When we went it was eggs with everything! Prices okay around £5 mark. Good for when visiting Tate. Nice environment. Def recommend visit if in the area

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom

tO5jmaTWjnWXTj7HmPE6PA.text: All the reviews of this place seem to be for brunch but I can confirm it is equally good for dinner. I ordered the veggie option which came fabulously presented (they're big on presentation it's the cafe for an architecture firm and design matters!) A huge platter of asparagus, artichoke, corgette and a duck egg everything was perfectly seasoned and cooked. The only slightly duff note was my strawberry and coconut cheesecake which was more like a mousse. My brother got the chocolate marquis and definately won the dessert round. Short menu which changes regularly (don't set your heart on the lobster with jerusalm artichokes advertised on the website as I did you will be left hearbroken!)The benches you sit on are heavy (be prepared for an upper body workout when you pull them out) but I think it's more glam than its cafe name would suggest and it has a lovely courtyard if the weather gets warm again. Recommended

1NxCTYDp3ljz-_gDPCUqaw.text: This is a breakfast and lunch place, (also serves dinner too) it has a canteen style to it, and it gets very busy during lunch as there are so many workers about this busy area. It has these wooden bench style seats, but nothing like how it was in school, very clean lines, and simple, all about the food. They have freshly baked bread, soup and favorites such as risotto, pasta, chilly con carne, shepherds pie or quiche type as options. There really is something for everyone.I have been there for brunch and very much enjoyed their eggs benedict and American style pancakes.Very good taste, perfect for a quick lunch catch up with a friend, or even eat alone as I did. It has a very relaxed atmosphere. It is reasonably priced and caters to the local community and office workers.

INg7S-wltQxeFVXGE_DqZw.text: A great place for a good lunch: The self service concept works well, and the atmosphere is buzzing. They have a great selection of very nice and varied salads, complimented by fish & meat dishes, sandwiches and extremely tempting deserts (though haven't tried the latter). Not for a romantic lunch (if there is such a thing) or an intimate Tête à Tête, but a great choice for unpretentious, good food.

LfD1p4XQxicwZI_uWrT6_w.text: Very surprised that this is a first review given some of the press this place has been getting lately. It really is a first-class lunch destination and I would imagine that it more than holds its own in the evenings as well. The dining area consists of a self-service counter and three or four rows of canteen-syle long tables and chairs. It's not a big space, but the design works very well, which is testament to the firm of architects who are responsible and who happen to have their offices above the restaurant. The menu is inventive, with a mix of cold and hot options and there is an emphasis on great ingredients (to be expected perhaps, with Borough Market just down the road). The staff are very professional yet still very friendly, and they seem to be enjoying what they do, which adds something to the vibe. Go take a look.

d2CqhC2Oc2zlvM5PNyJkow.text: Finally the area around the Tate is being filled with lovely eateries, it always surprised me that there was such a lack of choice around such a huge tourist attraction. That said, the few cafes, bars and restaurants which have sprung up along Southwark St and Bankside seem to have slipped under the radar of the tourist crowd which has got to be a plus! The Table has delicious food at excellent value, the atmosphere is relaxed and feels almost like an extension of nearby Borough Market but without the huge crowds. I've become a regular there for Saturday brunch and would gladly go on Sundays as well except they aren't open on Sundaysyet! Let's start a petition, who's with me!?

-92lo3dDCMnkwwwd0lI6Hg.text: I would move back to London just to be able to have their caramelized banana pancake. It's the most delicious pancake I have ever had. I once ordered the berries and chocolate pancake, and I regretted it -- it was good, but not amazingly good like the banana pancake. There's usually a line for brunch, so go early or be ready to wait.

9Q5jDL_3l7mB0P2K_iVIHA.text: Great brunch spot! Too bad it is really on a pretty unattractive street. Once you're inside though it's wonderful - yummy food and nice waiters. Delicious smoothies - pear apple and ginger hit the spot.

IGCXaT09TFZll4rGIIP_RQ.text: Thank u v much twitter 4 ur gr8 recm'dation! A few months ago, when I first began my journey into the world of twitter, I saw that one of my twitter foodie 'friends' was following a place called The Table Cafe (TTC) near Southwark Bridge on the South side of the Thames. I read some of their tweets and was impressed with their daily changing menu. I vaguely remember looking at their website too and noting their seemingly meticulous selection of suppliers, which ticked a lot of boxes (local, organic, etc.). Plus, they listed Monmouth as their coffee supplier, which is a good thing in my book. I kept telling myself the next time I was in that neighborhood (which is very rare), I must drop by and see what it was all about. Welcome to Sweden, can I take your order Walking into TTC, I felt as if I was entering someplace very familiar, but not exactly British. As far as I understand, TTC functions as the canteen for the firm of architects whose ground floor it inhabits (as well as the nearby office buildings). The exterior of the building is mostly glass, accented with angular flashes of bright yellow. Once inside, the clean modern lines and the use of simple and warm wood tables and benches immediately made both of us think of Scandinavia, and Sweden in particular for me. In fact, quite disturbingly, it reminds me of a particular haunt of mine in Stockholm. The fairly modest square room is replete with red rectangular sheets of metal on the ceiling, a long and narrow kitchen, a stock room that is half on display, a stainless steel espresso machine, and a wooden table on top of which some assorted juices, cereals, milks and fruits lay ready and waiting. As you can see from the photos below, cutlery and napkins are provided on the tables and the place settings are the paper menus. You order at the counter. The credit crunch brunch I would hazard to guess that TTC's main business is the weekday lunch crowd, and for that they have a daily changing menu which sounds pretty good and is amazing value with dishes from £2.85 (for a Spanish Tortilla made with free range eggs, heritage potatoes and sautéed white onion) upward. I say 'amazing' value because even the most expensive dishes (just under £8) are made from very high quality ingredients and seem very hearty. One of the staff members said they've only started opening on the weekends in the last few months and are still not set on exactly what times they should open for and what menu they should use (i.e. should it just be brunch all day, or brunch then lunch, etc.?). On our visit, the weekend brunch menu was available. It sounded very appetizing and, if any good, would be much better value than most places offering similar brunch menus in the West End. We made our decisions and sat back and waited for the food to arrive over a cup of tea. It was a Twinning's tea bag of Earl Grey by the way, which was surprising as all of their other suppliers seem to be so carefully chosen. But I like their Earl Grey the best of the major brands, so no complaints. After a good ten minutes, one of the chefs brought out the still hot plates to our table. We were a bit giddy as it looked like American sized portions, and visually both plates held a lot of promise. Mrs LF said the following about her breakfast stack: The toasted bagel was an original alternative to muffins, which are usually associated with poached eggs with hollandaise sauce. In this dish, the eggs were perfectly poached with a beautiful orangey yellow yolk as it was split open. The homemade baked beans were yummy, perfectly done and very special; how many places bother making their own baked beans these days? When it comes to baked beans, I tend to like Heinz, actually! But these were as much more delicious and satisfying. The hollandaise sauce was excellent in terms of taste (creamy and with the right amount of tang) and consistency. The chorizo sausage, however, didn't stand out (maybe they forgot to put it in?) as I don't actually remember eating it. Overall, it was very different compared to the breakfast we usually have at our favorite brunch places, which all tend to have the same items on the menu: English Breakfast, Eggs Benedict and so on. 8/10. My pancake looked and smelled beautiful. And I certainly wasn't let down by the taste either. The large and very thin pancake had been cooked through exactly right: the edges were slightly crispy and the middle was soft and fluffy but not at all doughy. The sweetness of the maple syrup and caramelized bananas contrasted well with the saltiness of the extremely crisp and thin streaky bacon. I know this is a very American flavor combination, and I personally love it, although I can understand how some people are not the greatest fans of the extreme sweet and salty combination for breakfast food. For me it all worked together perfectly, and I thoroughly enjoyed every bite. 8/10. Well worth the detour We thoroughly enjoyed our

peNrwCqK5kcragYov6OOsA.text: Best English Breakfast that I've had. Friendly staff. Quaint, but hip.

W9rm0tZ8CqoysyJnEiz0Yg.text: What more can one say? A proper English Brekkie and a well- lit location. Nothing more perfect to start the morning than with a cup of tea!

s50ziAf42COE1x-fby_sGw.text: Great place, great food, great prices for breakfast and lunch. This is located in a part of town where it is NOT so easy to find good food and so The Table is a real find. Everything was delicious. One day we went later in the day i.e. around 5 and The Table was closed so we went to the Mexican place across the street-- like similar places in NYC, and really not a bad second or third choice. But if you can get to the Table for lunch, go there!

nAEJ8D2VBnGA830-OMGCww.text: Great place for those who love to eat!I visited this place several times and I fell in love with the menu and atmosphere. I visited London for work and found this interesting and comfortable place for breakfast, lunch and dinner. I think it's a perfect place for simple meetings and different business meetings. The menu is very rich, colorful and  diverse. I tried several dishes and all of them were excellent. I took the Benedict eggs with a piece of sweet potatoes and everything was delicious and very, very tasty.

Ly5Cln2qIwGAK-ipHL0hEg.text: Originally I wanted to go to Regency Cafe to try English Breakfast for cheap, but it was too inconvenient to get there. So I came here instead since it was walking distance from my Airbnb. I think I'm just not a huge fan of English Breakfast cuz it wasn't that good. Service is good but this place is just like all the other overpriced brunch places.

vvG15dkxFqT-FEJ2auhfJQ.text: Great little place with great food.  The burger was excellent and the chips better then most pubs I've visited in the same neighborhood.  Would definitely recommend for anyone in the market for a great burger and chips.

h9pqkkv41GxH0jBLQx35zg.text: Straight up one of my favorite brunch places near central London.The place is beautiful with wide windows streaming with light. I've gotten full english and also this burger (forgot the name) here before and they were both really good. Came here with my sister once and she got the pancakes which I don't recommend because they were kinda basic and nothing too special (even though it was good). If you order one of their more special items off the menu, the portions are usually quite filling and the way they create dish is pretty special.They get pretty packed so recommend making a reservation or coming on off peak hours. Overall, love coming here.

b0hrgPJQBsE_7agbe_QaFg.text: This was the first stop on my vacation to the United Kingdom. My wife and I got went there from brunch on a Sunday. It was pretty crowded but we were able to get a table without a wait. It seems you can make reservations. I got a flat white and the Full English breakfast. Overall, I was impressed with the food. The Full English came with toast, beans, bacon, sausage, two eggs, mushroom and tomatoes. Each individual part was great - fresh ingredients and cooked well. The flat white was good. I'm not a espresso expert, but I did enjoy the drink.Service was great. They were friendly and got our orders out in a timely manner. A very clean restaurant and located less than a five minute walk from the Tate Modern. Good place for a meal if you are in the area.

U2vwtAmixEGaVviu8h7MIg.text: It's a cozy cafe, every time I visit London , I always choose Hilton Bankside which is only 2 mins to the cafe, and I like the brunch, the pancake and waffles there.

uHIcJTFxEz8mdBLycCaRfQ.text: We came to The Table Cafe for Sunday Brunch and it was absolutely AMAZING!!!  I highly suggest eating here.  When we come back to London we will absolutely return.

37flJfrpcm4nJ1IB8G4yrQ.text: Hidden gem on the bankside wir really tasty breakfast or brunch. I loved the avocado chicken sandwich with sweet potatoes- yummmmmm

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom

0zC3wPevbo_LhHQm4_09-Q.text: I love this place so much. The restaurant is so clean and their food is so delicious! It does get a bit busy but I haven't had to wait more than 5 minutes on the few occasions I've visited and they were slammed. Just get the eggs fallaw, (mine is on gluten free toast) you won't be disappointed. You're welcome!

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom

J8KW3sS0TO6GN3oXcx6E-Q.text: This place has a great selection of breakfast options. All meals of good quality. I would recommend.

MSsqOQCqmGIHRxWoKjKs9w.text: Just got off the plane. Was starving i found this place through yelp. Finally got to try the typical English breakfast. Everything was amazing!

yghisLfBlCw3KoAlLpkUmw.text: The food looks much better than it tastes. Went here for brunch before visiting Tate Modern, which is a 2 minute walk away. Got the veggie borough while the mister got the full English. Everything was either too bland or too salty. No depth of flavor. Three stars because the food came out really fast and the restaurant is very clean, modern, and bright.Would not go back.

mJxK3hQoDHGPtgSM5Vo2Mg.text: We went to The Table for brunch while visiting London. The reviews looked promising and they opened early which worked well for us.We were greeted and seated immediately. The menu was filled with many brunch options, many of which sounded delicious. This is what we ordered: two mochas and the brunch burger to share. (Disclaimer: we were still quite full from our dinner the night before so we decided to share the burger). The mochas were delicious but the star of the meal was the brunch burger. It was massive: It had fried egg, grilled pineapple, sausage, and veggies. Also came with a side of sweet potato fries. It was very filling and delicious. Just what we needed to start our day of exploring in London. The staff was friendly and the vibe was relaxed. The design is modern with an open kitchen where you can watch the chefs work. Definitely a great find.

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Brunch burger
Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Latte and cappuccino

bFIszVISrq7ame-kspa47g.text: Came in for brunch after reading some excellent reviews. The restaurant has a lovely atmosphere and is easily accessible. I arrived around 11:40 and was greeted by a friendly girl who notified me that the kitchen was closed until 12. No big deal, this would be my time to enjoy a proper cup of English tea. At 12, she came back and took my order. Eggs Benedict. What a lovely interpretation of a very famous dish. The bacon was succulent, the eggs perfectly poached (and not watery), and the tea strong with flavor. I will definitely be returning with my future visits to London.

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Eggs Benedict Perfection

hiDFamGWq6OTpUU1Ok6v4Q.text: Traveled quite some distance to have breakfast here. What I wanted was not available so that was quite disappointing. Regardless, it was hard choosing one plate off the menu since some many pictures off yelp made it look so yummy! My friend ordered the cappuccino and the full English breakfast while I ordered the chocolate waffle. Warning - the waffle was an extremely heavy breakfast. If you love chocolate and can handle that much sugar in the morning, go for it. The service was slow and the water service was even worse. This place tends to be packed.

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Full English breakfast
Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Chocolate waffle
Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Cappuccino

xS2LH2-dMO-b_97h_b2m-g.text: Normally (at least in the states), you can't go to a brunch place on Saturday during the hours of 10-2 and actually get a seat, but when we arrived to The Table Café, the hostess said only 15 minutes for 2 and we would be seated. We enjoyed the nice summer breeze and watched the happy brunch goers- everyone seemed to be really pleased with the food and the service. When we finally sat down, we ordered an apple juice and lady grey tea, 2 Forest Benedicts (poached eggs piled on avocado and bacon slices over an English muffin), and some lemon water. My boyfriend absolutely LOVED the fact that they didn't add unnecessary sides or "filler" to the meal like potatoes or anything (American style). You just get two eggs Benedict on the plate and we loved that. The service was amicable and quick and the food tasted absolutely delicious. I only didn't award 5 stars because I've been to my fair share of brunch places and it didn't WOW! me, but it really was very good. I'd recommend if you are in the area!

41-3KHnEWXlYmnqkbCrfDw.text: Decent food. Horrible service. Granted... we had just landed in London and were on no sleep and probably looked sloppy from the travel - but we were treated poorly despite us waiting nearly an hour while they transitioned menus.

d68e_mM-uPAL4GXpUbmyjw.text: I found this place on yelp. very nice restaurant. i had a really good eggs benedict. i like that they  had a few options for that dish. For a quick sit down breakfast a good location.

W3IsfVdvk_ZW3f_YKGbmxQ.text: The table is an excellent breakfast place. They do have lunch and dinner too but I have never tried and to be honest, it's a primarily a breakfast place.Try the eggs royal or eggs Benedict, they are well tasty, though quite pricey (but they are worth it).The coffee is very good too, they use Monmouth beans so it has a pleasant strong aroma...So, if you have your way past it in the morning, want a nice breakfast experience, well then it's worth the visit!

4tWbByisXR93hkxmhJm1Iw.text: FINALLY!!!  A proper English breakfast! My luck has been spotty so far with breakfast.  I actually had to return some eggs that over easy because the yolk was hard.But let's focus on the restaurant at hand.  The Table, while a bit off the beaten path, it's well worth the effort.  I chose to come here based on some fellow Yelpians giving it good reviews.A train ride and nice walk later, I end up at The Table.The Entrance is very open, modern, bright, and has a nice continental feel to it.  Once you come in, the sun pours into the space which is helped by an open kitchen.  I am a big fan of open kitchens.  They really give you a bird's eye view of how your meal is made.I sat at the back close to the doors to the patio.  (Picture Added)  Unfortunately, it was full.  The music is a great downtempo electronica that keeps the freshness of the space going throughout the meal.The menu is simple and to the point which helps the customer decide what to get with some confidence.  It's been a while since I've been there (sorry, I've been really busy and didn't have the time to do it right away), but it was the bagel with beans and chorizo with hollandaise sauce. (Picture included), coffee, and Orange juice.OJ -- freshly squeezed (or extremely fresh form a container)Coffee -- The best cup of Latte I have had in England.  A perfect balance of flavor and bitterness.  I didn't even have to add any sugar. (Picture Added)Double bean bagel delight. -- I got this with the Hollandaise sauce on the side since I usually think it's too much for the dish.  I get the dish and am amazed at the presentation and overall appeal of the dish.  I make the first cut into it and it's really rather bland.  I immediately get upset because so far this place rocks! I sit there and take a couple of more bites and then DING, it hits me!  You big Dummy, try the sauce on it.  So I take a dollop of Hollandaise and smack it on top of the bagel.  Once I take a bite, I fully understand the value of Hollandaise.  It added the tanginess that the dish was missing.  The creaminess the bagel was interfering with that the beans usually give.  The best breakfast I have had in England.I spoke with one of the employees and I told him to suggest to customers that they at least get the Hollandaise sauce on the side as the dish in incomplete without it.  In the US, we love the extremes of everything so Hollandaise is usually too much for my taste.I can't wait to go back in a couple of weekends.

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. The open kitchen
Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. The breakfast sandwiches of breakfast sandwiches
Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. The best Latte in London!

2qyucLLvmEF4ORT1D2xzIg.text: HA! Has anyone else read the quick description The Table left about themselves below? It starts off with: "Mainly we specialise in deliciousness..." which couldn't be closer to the truth. Gotta love a place that calls it like it is. And calls it correctly. Let's review:1. They are located in a veritable culinary no-mans-land2. They make everything they serve in house 3. They source all of their ingredients locally But don't take our word for it, trust your mouth! The moment you bite into whatever deliciousness you finally decide on (I managed to try the eggs benny, smoked salmon, sausage, bagel, pancakes, bacon, scrambled eggs, yogurt, granola, and even a cheeky sip of a smoothie before people started giving me strange looks. Ok, so I like to sample...)And I must say, I was not disappointed. With lovely strolling locations so nearby, I'll certainly be bringing every incoming set of summer visitors here, with a walk along Southbank or through the Tate planned afterward. In fact, I'm greatly looking forward to it!

Xl11bD2otlrvwnk88TchMw.text: On a first glance, The Table looks slightly devoid of atmosphere but I was very pleasantly surprised. Decor wise it is sleek and contemporary but also warm, friendly and chilled out due to the 'canteen' feel to the place. It is located in the headquarters of renowned architects Allies and Morrison so it comes as no surprise that significant but subtle attention has been paid to the interior.The service is really very good here and the staff are friendly and relaxed. The choice of food is also fantastic with a good variety of both meat and fish dishes. The presentation is lovely and the prices are actually quite reasonable for the quality. It isn't quite in the hub of SE1 so does tend to attract the local workers as opposed to a mixed crowd but it is definitely worth a visit.

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom

QNzz6eSe36CWb8jc7dskvw.text: One of the best breakfast I had lately. Food quality is outstanding. Service the same. Although the restaurant was full and we didn't have a reservation we were treated in a very friendly manner. Service was helpful and fast (not everywhere the case when every seat is taken). We had the full breakfast and eggs Benedikt and both were perfectly cooked and tasted well. A great combination to share :).

g_YM6eEFKWejnJditQDY_g.text: I'd been meaning to go to The Table for some time now but hadn't quite managed to find a day when I thought I could spare the calories. After all, I'd heard good things about their breakfast stack (which comes with their homemade baked beans), and, while tempted, I had just come from the gym after all, and opted for the unusual-but-seemingly-healthier combination of pancakes, maple syrup, caramelised banana and streaky bacon. and a flat white. The pancakes were really nice. The outer parts of the pancake were very crispy, much the way I like my food, but I suspect there are others who may not like that. While the pancakes were soaked in syrup, this was nicely set off by the saltiness of the crispy bacon. Sadly, the flat white was not as good as the pancakes. It was watery and weak, and, honestly, I was very tempted to leave the whole cup virtually untouched. Because I place such a great importance on coffee, I would ordinarily only have given The Table three stars. However, they've been incredibly responsive on Twitter (@thetablecafe), so I'm giving them an extra star for getting back to people so quickly when they're giving feedback. Anyway, after I finished my food, I realised there was a line of about seven people waiting for places. I must have been incredibly lucky, as I just walked in and got a place almost immediately about 45 minutes before that!

xpDA6x_DPwxz6rCodFjVNA.text: The wait was totally worth it! The food was delicious. I had the smoked salmon and scrambled eggs (no toast for me as I'm gluten-free). I don't know how they made such a simple dish taste so much better than every other restaurant, but they did. The meals of my fellow diners were also raved over. We also LOVED the tea they served. I emailed the restaurant after our meal to ask the brand of their (english breakfast) tea. The owner replied promptly and even offered to help me get some boxes if the company (teapigs.co.uk) didn't ship internationally (they do). Excellent customer service and excellent food for a good value. I highly recommend this restaurant.

Qn73WSHDr-WSLFGg-bwAJA.text: I'm currently having a love affair with bacon, making up for my misspent Jewish youth of a piggy free diet. Who would have thunk it! This cafe in an independent culinary no mans land is pretty brilliant. I came here today for breakfast meet up with 14 Yelpers on the recommendations I read here. It's actually been on my bookmark list for a while. I was not disappointed! Great value brunch and breakfasts, served in a relaxed and friendly manor on big communal tables. Perfect if you have a large group of you coming down! They not only do cooked breakfasts but yogurt, nuts and seeds for the bird like eaters.Only shame is you can't book and the coffee wasn't filter.

3CYsHS8FON98-EafqtaTOw.text: Best Full English I've had in London. Great food, awesome service! Just go!

7YlOPYL9wJtUuDjiNPa4aQ.text: Had a great brunch with friends here. Four of us waited about 20 minutes for a table on a Saturday at 11:30am. Food was very good, coffee was great- can't complain about anything would definitely go back

2WGt60zZJZdIypoLw17DeQ.text: One of those "meh" experiences. It was fine, just nothing special. There doesn't seem to be a lot of creativity in London, when it comes to breakfast. I get that they all these places are trying to do a special coffee, but the food here, and at a lot of the other highly rated breakfast places, seem to be doing late 90s, early 00s, breakfasts. Lantana is trying, but lets itself down with the service. There is a real gap for a creative chef or chefs to shake up the breakfast/brunch experience, in the same way that was done with coffee about two years ago.

dDBtKv8f1D9_LdvR8sIZow.text: I ate a stupendous portobello mushroom and halloumi sandwich in here, which oozed pesto and mushroom juices.  Corrr, just thinking of it makes me hungry.  My friend had a disappointingly flavourless pasta thing which really needed salt.I think serving unseasoned, crappy pasta is such a heinous Food Crimes 101 mistake that my confidence in their food is a little shaken, but I would gladly go have that sandwich again and ogle the wonderful interior design and food presentation.  It's in my 'very London' category,  all rather industrial chic, dahhhhhling, with steel surfaces and equipment on show, and rough wood benches.  Ready made sandwiches and delectable cakey whatnots tumble in a clever and lovely faux-rustic way on greaseproof paper and chopping boards.

0GGjgtOQbFyvGHLaY1gcZw.text: Its early in the morning, you happen to be around Southwark for the following reasons:a) you live round the areab) went for an early morning stroll/jog along the river Thames. c) after an intoxicating night out, you've ended up falling asleep on the Streets of Londonorb) meeting up with fellow yelpersIf you're feeling a little peckish and you fancy treating yourself to some good quality food, then The Table is the place to be.The Table was not what I expected it to be. Soon as I walked in, I was completely blown away by the modern decor and calm atmosphere.  The prices are sensible and the quality of the food is top. I got me eggs benedict, extra bacon and toast bread (I got abit excited) followed by a nice cup of early grey tea.Excellent customer service and I love the fact that staff are not in uniforms, it does not give that "systematic/chain type" image, which is great!Had the pleasure of meeting up with other yelpers. A great start to my day.

GcHL7PfYRO52EpNJdSdx6A.text: Gorgeous big bright room with remarkably cheery staff, big welcoming smiles and help offered - which was needed as they have no menus or boards up for breakfast and if you're a first timer - which I was - it's a bit confusing/intimidating when you walk in. But once I'd worked out the procedure I ordered a text book perfect flat white that a friendly waiter brought to me while I waited for a friend. When we were two I had good poached eggs on toast, slightly dry, but nice, my friend had the breakfast from the buffet - great muesli and juice followed by toast and jam. Consistently good coffee for the morning. We stayed for over an hour, without taking anyone's seat because it's nice and big and best of all has blocks of matcing tables running the length of the room with tucked in seating so you have your own 'territory' defined with no one getting the short straw of struggling to get in and out in the middle of the row. If you're round there well worth dropping in.

6YYaxadSQ_ncgA2kv7cCHw.text: The French toast brioche is amazing, particularly the one with grilled banana and bacon. Coffee is also great, all of this for a very reasonable price. I cut them a star for running out of waffles and disappointing my poor dining partner who had been craving waffles for ages, but otherwise so so good.

weBG5ihWzaa1hYl1r3b6AQ.text: Great breakfast, awesome service, happy to personalise our orders and kept the coffee coming.  Best breakfast I've had in London

7vpPDvg7qsb8ZktdY7bo7g.text: The Table is a nice modern breakfast place just 2 minutes from Tate Modern. I visited one saturday with a few friends. The place reminded me of the Ottolenghi on Upper Street. White walls, with long communal tables and bottles of wine on the shelves (but without the dazzling dessert display). The food is reasonably priced and very tasty. I had the scrambled eggs on toast. I got much more of the egg than i expected (it costs only £4). Even the others were happy with their orders ... ranging from simple eggs to smoked salmon.The only problem is that their billing system is a bit disorganized. Some people were asked to pay while ordering, some later. For those paying later, they frequently mixed up the orders. So you would do well to remember what you have eaten.To conclude, its a very useful place to go to for refreshments once in a while if you are living nearby or visiting Tate.

fMWUVCzEg7lQBES4SNu0lg.text: Update I promised I'd give these guys another try and I'm so pleased I did this morning. At OH MY GOD WHAT TIME in the morning (actually, 9am, but I'm a lazy freelancer), I found myself back here again. Surprisingly quiet for a rainy morning, I opted for poached eggs on toast with portobello mushrooms and was treated to excellent, nay, perfect eggs with runny yolks. I was happy as a clam and yummy noises and happy smiles were made about the bacon sandwich my companion was eating (he has in fact told me to mention how nice it was). The staff are friendly as ever (not least when I changed my mind at the counter three times because I hadn't had any caffeine) and I'm more than happy to bump them up to four stars. The final star is reserved for when they get free wifi. I might have got off to a rocky start with Table Cafe, but I really like it here. Update I wanted to really really really love this cafe. There isn't much in this area, and as I'm a south east London girl, I'm also on the hunt for cafes this side of the river so I can go to meetings without trekking all the way into Soho. I can reach London Bridge in 20 minutes, it's twice that to get into central. I had a chat with Table Cafe on Twitter and they were lovely. I really liked their approach, and their service. But my eggs ben wasn't up to scratch. The eggs weren't runny (which too me is the key part of the dish) and the hollandaise was just too sharp for my tastes. I reckon I'd give Mr. Hinchcliffe a run for his money as 'King of Egg Benedict in London' and this just didn't stand up for me. I like the setting, I loved the freshly squeezed fruit juice (although it's unclear if it's bottomless, we doubted it was, but the 'pour your own' could get confusing and we didn't want to get told off). I really enjoyed my morning here. I will come back, I think my eggs were a disappointing one off, but unless they get better next time, they're staying on three stars. Always happy to give places another shot, especially when I like everything else, so I'll keep you posted.

QQjuEdjV5YszunbZVJZCug.text: A nice little hidden gem. I love the place, it has this amazing atmosphere and a great service available. The menu is also suitable for every taste as it has many different types of food and drinks. The place is truly great and I recommend it.

eAWUWWdgkCrtBBt4YJYhdA.text: Well, I had one of those rare, disappointing experiences where Yelp led me in a bad direction. There was absolutely nothing I liked about my experience at The Table Cafe.First, the food was bland, greasy, and gross. I ordered the farmer's market breakfast, which is normally two fried eggs, potatoes lyonnaise, and sausage, but I substituted the sausage for smoked salmon instead.The eggs were totally fine, but the potatoes were flavorless and greasy and the salmon was incredibly dry and had so much gross fat and connective tissue that I could only eat about 50 percent of it. After my meal, I felt kind of sick.My experience at Table Cafe wasn't made any better by the service. There was a sign by the door that said I should wait to be seated, but no one welcomed me when I went in so I had no idea where I should go. Eventually I just wandered up to the front counter to order, where they told me to find a table. After I finished eating, no one brought me the bill so I went back up to the front counter to pay. I usually trust Yelp, and this place does have a lot of great reviews, but in my experience Table Cafe was gross and incredibly expensive.

Me_slO-jPmixJE_zgHiIDQ.text: Found this place by accident on a bank holiday, walking around looking for something open! What a lucky find! I had the veggie benedict with avocado and grilled halloumi- so delicious, healthy, hearty. My sister had the veggie borough and it was perfect before a long morning of sightseeing. Airy, bright atmosphere with a cozy garden vibe. This would be an excellent spot for brunch or a celebration breakfast.

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Tea and cappuccino (with cocoa dusting)!
Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Veggie Borough and Veggie Benedict! Delish!

yYrnwx9ibu-4D7T_oUBzyg.text: This place is absolutely terrific! My wife and I arrived in London for our trip on the red-eye, and after a sleepless (and very quick) night on the plane and a morning spent at customs and trying to get to our hotel in rush hour (which we finally did), we were starving, exhausted, and in need of coffee. A quick Yelp search revealed that there was a bistro just a 2-minute walk from our hotel. I made a quick reservation for lunch and we strolled down the street moments later.Upon arriving, I noticed how clean and open the space looked, complete with indoor seating and outdoor seating (perfect for a beautiful summer day like the one we experienced, although we chose to dine inside). A few moments after being seated, our waiter came by with some water and took our drink orders. My wife and I both ordered coffee. After perusing the menu, we then decided on our entrees. My wife ordered the full English breakfast while I ordered the all-day breakfast pancake.After maybe 20 minutes, our food arrived, and the presentation alone was wonderful. We took a few "insta-worthy" (and Yelp-worthy) photos and then took our first few bites. Man was that pancake delicious! It had a slightly crispy exterior and soft interior that was just cooked too perfectly, and the scrambled eggs, bacon and leek sausage on top provided the perfect complimentary flavor. Meanwhile, my wife really enjoyed the Full English breakfast, complete with scrambled eggs (substituted for fried eggs), bacon, leek sausage, homemade baked beans, a roasted tomato and roasted mushroom. Everything was superb!I have to admit, the food was so good that we went back the next day as well. This time, I opted for the Spring chicken (with grilled English sweet corn and bacon mash in a garlic butter sauce) and my wife ordered the all-day pancake. Everything was out of this world!So why only the 4 stars? The service was not quite a 5-star establishment. There were times we felt like we were getting the cold shoulder. That being said, if we asked for something (water, the check, etc.), we eventually got it. Nevertheless, I wouldn't let the service spoil the culinary experience. The food is terrific and worth the trip!

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Boneless spring chicken with bacon mash in garlic butter sauce
Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Delicious pancake!
Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Full English breakfast

Y3WSwSukEuWhMbdryJkR6g.text: Waiting in the cold and damp for 45 minutes staring at eight free tables the entire time I had convinced myself was all going to be worth it if the food lived up to the hype. Sadly, it didn't. Not even close.I had the Full Borough English with black pudding, eggs over easy, bacon extra crispy, and a Fellini Bellini. Let's start with the good. The Bellini was great, the fizz to purée ratio was spot on and I loved the strawberry flavour. The sausage was well seasoned, great texture, the tomato was juicy and sweet, and the sourdough was tasty. Now let's talk about the, um, beans. One clue is that if you're looking at baked beans and they're bright white, you know your tomato sauce is not rich or plentiful enough to cover them. They were also tiny, like the Tesco Value ones, and mixed with an anemic pulled pork. Pork and beans are usually as perfect together as karaoke, soju and 80s rock ballads, but The Table fumbled both dishes and then hoping no one would notice, shoved them together. Did anyone in the kitchen even taste what they made? Poorly seasoned, poorly executed. I could tell you the black pudding was cereal heavy and therefore very dry, or the eggs tiny and fried so impatiently the white was crispy and the yolk more 'kinda stressed out' than 'easy like Sunday morning'. But you're skim reading at this point...As a Brit living in NYC, I have become used to a level of service that still, you know, tries. Despite a coven of waitresses standing around gossiping and side-eyeing patrons, there was no silverware on the table and the turnover of tables seemed glacial. Speaking of which, we were seated by the door despite open tables elsewhere (and knowing we were chilled to the core because of the long wait) which is just careless at best, or kinda mean. When your waitress asks 'How was everything?' you say 'Sadly average' and she ignores you, you know that they have enough people queuing not to care that they could have done so, so much better. Except if this level of cost-cutting on the food and overstaffing on bored, passive aggressive servers continues, you'll find the queues dry up just like the black pudding.

cZZPMtN9ZQMt9I2w4snKUQ.text: Food: highly recommended- very tasty and have diverse flavors even in one dish. Environment: offer outside seats.  Queue: I came on Saturday at around 12:00, I waited for around 25min for a seat.

Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Bacon/Banana/Waffle

-ENo9ZTnsVKa-iMiZg51Mg.text: Absoutley worth the wait we were planing to have breakfast but ended up being a late lunch at 3.30pm but still opted for a breakfast option. Staff were friendly food was absoutley delicious the all day breakfast that comes with  crispy but incredibley fluffy waffles I don't know how they do it. Fluffy eggs, bacon a little to crispy for my taste and gorgeous sausages. My friend ordered blueberry with waffles again the same excellent quality of waffles the blueberries brought a loveley sour twist to her rendition of waffles and little one ordered plain pancakes and for plain they were pretty good. Perfectly crisp on the outside and wonderfully fluffy on the inside. Generous portions hot chocolate was OK. Will defiantly be going back again to try the other amazing goodies on the menu. Seating area outside looked nice but unfortunately it was chucking down with rain. My only real complaint is they close by 4pm over the weekend.

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Sausages were fantatic, eggs super fluffy and waffles an absolute dream
Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Stunning waffles with sour blueberries brillant, crispy and fluffy I don't know how they do it
Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Little one wanted plain pancakes, as plain as they were they were also delicious slight cripys on the outside and fluffy on the inside

hrcYbCHWG1S1Ldk3fZil1Q.text: Really cool brunch place. Went in the early morning on a Tuesday and it is not crowded at all. I can tell that they put a great time and thought into their dishes. I ordered the Veggie Borough based on Yelp recs and it was very good. Not a fan of baked beans even though these were tasty and not as strong as others I've had in the past. I also asked for scrambled eggs instead of fried and they made it using a lot of cream which I liked. Didn't really like the spinach or tomato but they went well with the halloumi, which I didn't like at first but definitely started to towards the end of the meal. The best part of the meal was easily the mushroom. They were extremely thick, juicy and the green sauce on top of it was extremely tasty and went really well with the mushroom. I would've been fine with just the mushrooms as a meal. I also got the free Fried Chips, but thought they were a little too overfryed and too hard to eat. Overall, definitely lives up to the hype and hopefully can come back to try some more of the dishes.

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Fried Chips
Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Vegetarian Borough

I36HkV178aTcyDASUlbtRA.text: Came here with my friends for weekend brunch! The place is modern and bright with plenty of outdoor seats in the summer. I got the All-day Breakfast and it was delicious! It comes with bacon, pork & leek sausage, scrambled eggs, and a choice of waffles or pancakes. I went for the waffles and they stayed crispy to the last bite! I also got to try my friend's Pumpkin Patch pancakes. The pancakes are made with roasted pumpkin with some caramelized pecans and fresh berries as toppings. The portion for this was a bit small but it was unexpectedly tasty and unique. Most importantly, the pancakes were crispy! I highly recommend trying it! We also got some Herby Mushrooms as a side. These were perfect to go with everything. I'd come back again for brunch as I have a feeling that everything else on the menu will taste just as good!

h_-ghq9sKbPxIMx4yn0PoQ.text: - full english breakfast, large portion, comes with the classics, "herb" that came w/ the large portobello mushroom was reminiscent of pesto but without the parmesan or pine nuts- eggs benedict, good but not great, will likely get something else the next time I'm here, wish egg was a bit runnier and there was a bit more hollandaise, was a touch dry- the southwalk spritz was refreshing - simple clean execution of fresh ingredients - outdoor space- airy and relaxed atmosphere- quintessential brunch place

q8KVfCph32beb69M8UsYFA.text: We walked into the restaurant before a full day of tourism for brunch and, despite being super busy, the staff gave us amazing service and the food was the best we had the entire trip, as we were visiting from Washington, DC. I thank them for humoring a table full of boisterous Americans for almost two hours.

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. The french toast

WwnxwwprOaDK-FzGAiubfw.text: Great place for brunch! Was visiting London for work and only had a couple days to explore. Came to The Table Cafe because it had good reviews on yelp and was a short bike ride away from where I was staying. The atmosphere was warm and inviting, with open windows where you can get a good view of the street. I came around 9 am on a Tuesday morning and the restaurant filled up soon after my arrival.I had my very first traditional English breakfast here along with their fresh squeezed orange juice. It came with two eggs over toast, beans, mushroom, bacon, sausage, tomato, and I ordered black pudding because I was feeling adventurous. I enjoyed everything except for the black pudding (lol) and the bacon was a bit on the salty side.Free wifi is a plus! I had no cell service :-)

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Traditional English breakfast with black pudding (blood sausage) and freshly squeezed orange juice

LBtWELzHTxfFh113l3KHvQ.text: Great spot for breakfast! My husband and I came here around 9am on a Monday and you can tell this place is popular. People kept coming in and there were many reservations (marked on the tables). The outdoor are looked nice but we were sat inside. I overheard the entire outside area was reserved. So if you want to sit out there, make a reservation. The food portions were huge! My all day breakfast came with a massive pancake, 3 pieces of bacon, a full sausage link and I'm guessing 2-3 scrambled eggs. I ended up eating about a third of what I ordered. Again it was so much good! Everything was delicious but the pancake was the star of my meal. It was buttery, fluffy and just all around delicious. Meal for 2 (with one glass of OJ) was 27£

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Traditional English breakfast
Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. All day breakfast with a pancake

qCX8uHgSlBVMvvB0bCxBLA.text: I. Love. This. Place.  If you get get there early, there are plenty of seats.  The space was clean, simple, and modern.The veggie borough was wonderful (there's both a vegan and a vegetarian option).  Two eggs, grilled halloumi, spinach, baked beans, herb mushrooms, grilled tomatoes, sourdough toast.  Substantial and flavorful.  Fantastic.  Service was great.  Attentive.  Check this place out if you have the time.

Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Tea & coffee

rGsV5n7K0SNXF57vTTyRlA.text: I got the Veggie Borough and really liked the halloumi! Everything else was tasty - I was pleasantly surprised by the baked beans - but not necessarily extraordinary. I was momentarily disappointed by the portion sizes until I remembered I was in England, not the US, and this was probably a reasonable amount of food to consume. Great place for casual brunch!

PFraMR9RpeJJdPmic32Yag.text: My family of 5 stopped here for breakfast/brunch before going to the Shakespeare Globe Theater, and experienced some of the best food and service we've encountered during our vacay in London. The wait staff was friendly, and kept the water coming! I ordered the All Day Waffle and my family declared it  the best waffle we have ever eaten. It tasted like part funnel cake. The sausage and bacon on the platter were equally tasty and perfectly cooked. The other four members of my family had Eggs Benedict (one with salmon, the other three with bacon) and the Hollandaise was rich, buttery, smooth and the eggs were perfectly poached. Yum!!! They have a charming outdoor seating area.  I highly recommend!

Q6Wv-Vl6Aazfnkuhl0_SsQ.text: Apparently they do not give a sh*t of their costumers. When I asked to change a seat when my GF does not feel too good because of the current position is too cold, they refused my request even while there is apparently other empty seats not occupied. Such a RUDE behavior a British restaurant. So, prepare yourself for some uncomfortable service experience here if you ever plan to attend this place.

nuVs_prT_TNcJ5FnZwHZGQ.text: Awesome brunch spot in central London. Their portions are not too big and not too small. I got the eggs Benedict with a side of sweet potatoes (hey we're to die for!). I had a large group with me and we sat outside in their heated tent (during the month of February). I was warm, comfortable, and pleasantly surprised at how great the tent was during such a cold and rainy month

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom

XAKF9Q0FYvOQyvfbCJ5-Wg.text: Two of my friends and I stopped in on a Sunday morning for breakfast. I ordered the Breakfast Bruschetta (Sliced tomatoes & avocado on sourdough toast, two poached eggs & streaky bacon). It was pretty basic. Maybe even less than basic. It seems like they just threw it together. They took a hard piece of toast, added some chewy bacon, layered it with some sliced tomatoes, placed two small halves of avocado, and then topped it with two poached eggs. I would hardly call this a bruschetta. "Things on toast" would be a more accurate description. It was very difficult to eat. You definitely need a fork and knife for this situation. Not sure where all if the great reviews are coming from.

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Avocado toast with poached eggs

26Up2D1MR3-6yjooxFz_Yw.text: One of the best breakfasts / brunches I've had in England.  Try the Waffle. It's crisp but not too heavy. The Eggs Benedict was great too, with a hint of vinegar in the poached egg.

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Eggs Benedict
Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Breakfast Bruschetta
Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom

5cEB-Z3MzhwOOxy_mdxRHw.text: Really rude and arrogant attitude from the Manager.I went for brunch with my family. When we arrived I asked for a table and straight away there was an attitude from the manager, however I ignored it and as we were told there would be at least a 30 minute wait for a table, he took my name and we popped for a coffee at the Black Sheep Coffee place next door. We went back within 15 minutes. When I returned I asked where we were in the queue and the manager laughed in my face and said he already said my name out so had given my table to someone else. He then ignored us and started sitting other parties including people who had just arrived. I then asked if we were going to be able to get a table and in a very patronising and smug tone he started to re explain to me what had happened. So rather than put up with anymore rudeness we left and we found somewhere else. It's a shame because the food looked good.

jUEqB3OJIqmk0T0v3rHB8Q.text: Enjoyed Sunday Brunch, with the French Toast and Pumpkin Pancake.  Very flavorful and really good. (Every plate coming out of the kitchen looked really good!).  Highly recommend checking this place out.

PP0l0-O19YYIBlpKUwYVkA.text: Come here for breakfast a lot. Amazing food but getting a bit bored with the menu - be amazing if they could change it up a bit!

NYB2gHllZDsuIH0pWTNw5Q.text: Having read a few glowing Yelps about The Table's weekend breakfast experience I thought I'd sample the goods. The menu has the usual range of breakfast fare, like eggs, pancakes, and bagels. There are shishi touches like "ham hock baked beans". For my money, there's already enough pork in a full English. My full English was a large as it was delightful. For me, sausages make or break an English breakfast, and The Table excelled in this department. The bacon was also deliciously crispy - none of that colorless and insipid leather.  Sadly the ensemble wasn't piping hot, forcing me to rush. However, when I pointed this out, the waiter listened patiently, and offered us free drinks. The staff were friendly and efficient. I was initially sceptical about paying £10-12 for a breakfast dish, but on reflection prices were justified given the quality of the ingredients. Postamble (should be a word, I feel): The Table faces North, so it doesn't get any morning sun. I have a long-held fantasy of enjoying a divine breakfast while bathed in sunshine, so please let me know if you know such a place, so I can be complete.

ZFcGHOOjUh6UmsNlNgjX0Q.text: I would give this place 5 stars, but because the food came out cold...I just had to rate it a down a notch. My friends and I are staying in Waterloo for 3 months and we wanted to venture on some breakfast spots. The Table was a decent spot to try. We ordered eggs benedict, a baguette breakfast sandwich, early grey teas, and a cappuccino. Overall food was decent (the eggs benedict was cold), but I suggest ordering tea and coffee here with a small bite. The service was decent and the decor of the cafe is quite clean and cut and lovely.

olrprAi8iDQShJYGjBoBCQ.text: The Table cafe does a really great breakfast and lunch. It's always busy but I've never had to wait too long to get a seat. Good vegetarian options, and always great smoothies/milkshakes/fresh juices. I usually get eggs in one of the numerous varieties, but waffles and pancakes are a must to try out. The sweet corn fritters are really good too if you want something savoury.

a47VN4AN63q7dfq0R7Q6lw.text: This place was DELISH! The decor was awesome.. modern and chic. the dessert pancake i shared with my friend was mouth-watering!! sooo good!oh and we were looking for a place to munch on a breakfast before heading to Tate Modern.. it was perfect location!thumbs up! It was great!

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. cappuccino
Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. buttermilk pancake with berry compote, vanilla yoghurt and Valrohna chocolate
Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. buttermilk pancake with berry compote, vanilla yoghurt and Valrohna chocolate

9etPjPCSOjhGW1KU050LfA.text: I had the Borough Full English and it was a hefty amount of food.  Everything on the plate was cooked perfectly and all the right tastes were there.  Mushroom was tender yet not soggy and the eggs were prepared just right.Expecting a line based on the popularity of this place on Yelp, I actually only waited about 10 minutes to be seated around Noon on a Sunday.I went alone and was seated next to a delightful "bachelorette party".  It livened up the solo dining experience greatly.  I actually ordered the food I did based on one of their party members doing the same.The vibe is good.  Everyone was generally in a good mood.  The place is bustling though so don't go expecting a calm, quiet atmosphere.The service could have been better overall but I hardly noticed as I wasn't in a rush nor did I mind continuing my conversation with my new local friends.My only recommendation to the restaurant is that they place a sign on the door that says "Push" as everyone, myself included, first attempts to pull as pushing would bump the door into someone waiting in line to be seated.All in all, after a few weeks in London, this was one of my more enjoyable meals.

pK817iBMoo4PV5Jx31X8sw.text: Today was my second outing to The Table in as many weeks. Last week I went for brunch and had the sweetcorn fritters with tomato compote, spinach and poached eggs. And today I went for lunch and had the ranch burger with fries. The restaurant itself is pleasant and simply decorated. There is an open kitchen and the majority of the seating is on shared benches (a bit annoying if there you are sandwiched between two other parties all trying to have different conversations). My brunch experience was satisfactory, both my cousin and I felt that the sweetcorn fritters were not "sweetcorny" enough although the eggs, hollandaise and spinach were nothing special to write home about but still nice enough for me to want to return to sample some other things on the menu. Which brings me to today's lunch. The ranch burger is served with the obligatory brioche bun (perhaps a bit too browned in the oven), the patty itself (I was pleased to note that this is one of the dwindling number of places that will still serve a burger medium rare), their "secret sauce" (a dill, mayonnaisey/hollandaisey concoction with a hint of horseradish), generous chunks of gherkin (served outside the burger so that if, like me, gherkins are your arch enemy, they can be easily avoided) and a nice portion of fries. Now I have to get a bit negative :( In contrast to my companions' fries mine seemed to have an inordinate amount of salt. I tasted them and sure enough they were so salty my tongue was crying. Annoying when the other fries on the table had no such problem. Of course there will always be wall inconsistencies between dishes but to dump an ocean of salt onto one plate and not realise is just ridiculous. To give credit where credit is due I attracted the attention of our waitress (nb this took a while despite the restaurant not being that busy), and she was very apologetic and helpful. She immediately took my plate over to the kitchen and showed the chef. I saw him taste some of the fries, pull a little face and then quickly turned to the cooker to make me some more (oh the joys of an open kitchen, nothing can be hidden!) Within 5 minutes I had a bowl of fresh and appropriately seasoned fries which were delicious. I'm giving 4 stars and not 5 because of the fries incident and the difficulty I had in attracting the attention of the waitress, a problem which arose again when we wanted to pay. But don't let this deter you, both times I enjoyed the food and would go again. A hint for anyone thinking of going, book in advance as it does get rather busy around lunchtimes and if you'd like a bit more space and privacy request one of the stand alone tables at the side of the restaurant.

VPWM_Q9JYACcg048xqxxCw.text: FINALLY - a place in London that serves brunch almost all day. Where have you been?Went this past weekend - had the corn fritters with poached eggs which were absolutely amazing. Hollandaise was perfect.Boyfriend had the full english which looked pretty good as far as the full english goes.Only disappointment was the banana bread which was a bit burnt and covered in syrup to I think cover up for the burning, so that was sad but I was so full from the awesome fritters that I didn't care. I will definitely go back and probably go for the BACON pancakes next time. Yum yum tum!

kBWJ9KrRWd2yFVQFshcaEA.text: I was staying in the fabulous CitizenM hotel around the corner and needed brunch pretty desperately, so decided to give The Table another shot. This time it was much better.Food:- I went for the eggs benedict this time around, and was really happy with it. The eggs were perfectly poached, the bacon plentiful and crispy, and the hollandaise was just right. Tangy and flavourful without overpowering the eggs and bacon. Yum. It was about £8, and very good. - Husband had the Full English, and made quick work of it. He said it was one of the nicest posh English breakfasts he's had, and ranked it on par with the one at Ziloufs (our favourite restaurant in London). It was £12, so on the higher end of pricing for them, but he said it was very good. - Coffee was okay. I am a firm believer that good coffee doesn't need sugar. If prepared properly, a latte should already be sweet enough (lactose, yo). However, I needed two spoonfuls of sugar in my coffee. I suspect it was too hot or possibly the beans overroasted, Starbucks style. Not sure why, but it was more bitter than my ex. I will opt for a juice blend in future.Service:- Much better than last time. Quicker, friendlier, and with a sense of humour. Good stuff.Layout:- Still nowhere to put your coat (there's a rack in the back of the restaurant by the loos, but space is limited and I wouldn't use it unless I was sitting near it).- The tall table is preferable in my opinion - individual stools and ample space behind you to tuck a small suitcase out of the way.- Pairs will likely have to share their table with random strangers. Great if you're extroverted and like meeting new people. Bit awkward if you're hungover or trying to have a personal conversation.If you're going to need a table for 4 or more, book it ahead. We got there on a Saturday morning around 11:00 and didn't have to wait for a table for 2. We did have to share our 4-top with a random dude by the end, though. Little bit awkward.I think I would go back again if I were in the area. I wouldn't trek out to SE1 for it, though. I stand by my earlier assessment that it is a little over-priced. It's nice food, but some of the menu items are £1-2 more than I think they should be. That's not a dealbreaker for me, though, and it definitely beats a Pret bacon buttie.

EmRtiHnoYs9F1RX2wrLX1A.text: The tables are cool here..I guess they'd have to be..the food was unfortunately less memorable. The steak and soup were oil bug nothing to rave about!

ovdpTLLWCTwb8jv-x5RmIA.text: I had the corn fritters with poached eggs and my husband had the full English. The fritters were light and fluffy, spinach was fresh and eggs were perfect. The sausages almost tasted as though they'd been bbq'd. This was by far, the best breakfast we've had since moving to England in August. Looking for a reason to make a trip back to London and enjoy another fabulous brunch.

YvhZjIUwRx4N8JvFGlDRFA.text: You know you're going to be in for a good experience when the people that work in a venue are obviously proud of the fact. I think this can certainly be said of The Table after seeing how much care goes into everything they do.I went for dinner after seeing an amazing offer on Yelp of 60% off the bill in acknowledgement of a new menu.  I wasn't really sure what we were in for as the restaurant is located in an area not known for quality.We started with some expertly made cocktails. They haven't got a complicated cocktail menu but have some delicious classics. This are expertly created at a low bar along one side of the room and delivered by the barman. After recently having cocktails at several other restaurants I can certainly say that these were more than worth the £7.50 they charge. The glass isn't  filled with crushed ice with only a dribble of cocktail. No, these are proper sized drinks that will last you.The food was all fairly classic, including a green bean salad, smoke eel paté and smoked haddock fish pie. It was probably some of the most flavour packed food I've ever had. Portions were also well judged, thankfully leaving just enough room to have a delicious dessert.This place isn't just about the bacon sarnies. This is quality food and drink all day every day. Why not 5 stars? It had nothing to do with the service or the food. There was just something about the ambience that didn't grab me. Maybe it's because my seat was facing a wall. I'm definitely going back to see if I can give them the fifth star.

TPsfHQZC1O8PJXq0wglMQg.text: While visiting London, my husband and I went to The Table Cafe for a late breakfast.  I loved my meal-portobello mushroom omelette, tea and granola yougurt parfait.  It was delicious and healthy.  My only complaint was the ridiculous trying to be trendy music in the background that kept making me giggle.  But I guess if it made me giggle I shouldn't be complaining.  You can see the cooks making your food and there was a cook with braided facial hair, which also made me giggle.

ZjQL2Il1NX2QMFIFMOEuTg.text: Brunch! One of my favourite meals. Better than midnight feasts or elevenses. The table has a good brunch menu, served in nice surroundings, in a sort of unexpected location, by nice people. We did have to wait 20 minutes but once seated, weren't hurried. To the food - most thngs come with hollandaise and a poahced egg, which is all good by me. I had the sweetcorn fritters, topped with poached eggs and hollandaise, and served with a really good tomato chutney. The fritters themselves were just ok - if I went back I'd have benedict instead - but the hollandaise was indeed excellent. Also noteworthy good coffee. To end we shared a pancake (notice - singular), which was delciious with yoghurt and berries and syrup, but I was very glad I hadn;t ordered it as the main event - I'd have been hungry and a pancake is a pancake is a pancake. The pancake felt sort of expensive but the prices were just the right side of reasonable. A long way for me to go for brunch but I'd make the trip again, and I'd like to try it for dinner.

JadB9fFfDH6aES-ehG53LQ.text: Nice place and good service but I had the shack and I didn't like it. Will go back but will choose something different.

VH7zdsIMxPe_5N9nUVGnBg.text: Great place for good stylish english breakfast. For egg lovers lots of options. Brunch and breakfast menu available throughout. Portion size gives good value for money. True blue and the veggie borough  offer delightful hearty brunch combination.

lTTFi3hH8BvlwXxthYH16A.text: The Table Café is local to my day job  and it's where I go for fabulous food. They do incredible granola (I know who raves about granola right!!?) I do  since I had theirs because simply: it is fabulous. The breakfast is my particular favourite meal here although they serve a great lunches and the table service is fast, but it's busy at lunch times so get in early! They also deliver locally so if you're doing a morning meeting you could have the granola delivered!! (Obsessed? Moi!?) The coffee. Oh the coffee, it's good, it's very good. For an alternative to chain restaurants in the area this is a great place for a meal. My tip for this one  treat yourself and have breakfast here! It ROCKS! Honest!

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom

IH3JUVvFByw33lRohQEZuA.text: Had their Morning Glory smoothie and coffee the other day, and both turned out to be quite good. However, I was disappointed with the portion of the smoothie for the price. I am sure they use good quality fresh ingredients for their smoothies but wish it was more.Will try breakfast/brunch there soon.

D97Zw9gqIdNr4UReCS004w.text: What can I say about The Table really - probably the best cafe in London. Everything is cafe made and everything is cooked thoughtly and skillfully and it's priced correctly.  I've eaten here 50 times maybe over the last 2 years and cannot complain about anything I've eaten. Highlights:-- Bacon baguettes are legendary-- Recently got into their English muffins with bacon and egg-- Flat whites are brilliant, made using Monmouth coffee-- Their cafe made cookies and cakes are first class!Unfortunately it's considerably better during the week than it is at weekends, it's  bit of shambles service wise then.  They change the payment system and it just doesn't work.  If you get a chance to visit try 12 - 1.30 during the week. I'm pretty critical when it comes to food but this place is so consistent, not sure where they got the chefs from but impressive.

vp0zZpeqx7d-QHC6ALiKag.text: Been here a couple of times for dinner. The first was a five star experience, and the second a three.On both occasions there was a fantastic vibe and friendly, chatty waiters. However, the speedy service and spot-on grub were sadly lacking on our second visit.I think both of these were simply down to the fact that they were busier on the second occasion, and there simply weren't enough staff, both front of house and in the kitcheni.Whilst I had been blown away by the food on my first visit, my second involved a rather strange, tiny main meal which was served to me in the bottom of a saucepan (it wasn't recognisable from what I had ordered on the menu) and inedible, stringy green beans. It's a shame as the chefs are obviously talented. They were just too busy and details got overlooked.Anyway, we had a fantastic time on both occasions and would certainly go back.

yR5pPxDrm-qTwbpRsnT_ug.text: Awesome brunch, everything was perfectly cooked. Great portions and relaxed atmosphere. Food envy of our surrounding diners too! Will definitely be returning.

iZ716Dk2F4jLtynboCb8gw.text: Very friendly personnel and the food is really worth standing in queue for. A little bit crowded and recommend to get there early as the line starts before noon. Easy on weekdays.

photos.caption: Photo of The Table - London, United Kingdom. Vegetarian breakfast, flavor explosion!

McyDSf4aoBAleI1n4KuqmA.text: This is a very popular place to go for Sunday brunch.  So much so that we were waiting by the door for a while before we were shown to a table.  We recommend someone to be responsible for meeting people at the door.  Only if no-one is there should they move to clearing the tables, but as soon as someone comes in, then they should attend to them.The food, however, was a better experience.  I ordered the pancake and bacon and banana.  I was really impressed with it when it arrived - very thick pancake with generous servings of caramelised banana and bacon.  My wife had the Borough English breakfast, which came with all of the delicious components you would expect.  This is the driver of my favourable 4-star rating.We had ordered coffees soon after we were seated, but they arrived pretty much at the same time as our meals.  The coffees tasted good.It took a while for us to pay our bill after we asked for it.  It was somewhat difficult to get anyone's attention.

q8_w2Pcy9H3VEH0rW8_RVw.text: I have returned repeatedly to the Table and remain in love. Their eggs benedict are amazing! I have been to various posh breakfast places and so far nothing matched the Table. Ive pretty much had everything from their salty part of the menu and would recommend it all.Ps the beans are still awesome

-iEmYfLLkGTBwVCSD_QyVg.text: The best proached egg brunch I have tried so far!!  Those running egg yolk is so yummy! After check reviews,  I also tried the sweetcorn fritters,  interesting texture,  like those two drops of green chilly sauces.Pancake is fluffy, huge and thick , but I may prefer the smaller round shape ones with more creams and fruits in other venue. I am too full to try their famous waffle,  will surely come back to try it! Their smoothie is good but suggest to have more choices. My Friend tried the burger,  but complain the Bacon is too salty and affect the overall taste of beef. Setting is casual and relaxed, but due to the table layout, it can be noisy sometimes if u want to catch up with your friend when the place is busy. Still recommend for a Sunny day!
